name: New ways of seeing
description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

key_work.title: Stereoscopic viewers and cards
key_work.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

constellations_primary.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_primary.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

end.title: Stereoscopic and 3D devices
end.brief_description: These objects at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image connect 3D technology from stereoscopic viewers in the 1800s to the Viewmasters of the 1980s.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: The first objects that visitors encounter in The Story of the Moving Image trace the evolution of stereoscopic viewers, from the antique to the easy and innovative, like Google Cardboard.

end.title: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat
end.creator_credit: Louis Lumière, Auguste Lumière and Lumière
end.brief_description: The Lumière brothers’ famous actuality film of people waiting for a train to arrive at La Ciotat.

constellations_other.name: The Lumière brothers
constellations_other.description: The Lumière brothers understood the potential of cinema to be exhibited theatrically. Only one person could watch films through Thomas Edison's Kinetograph, while Auguste and Louis exhibited their films to thousands with Cinematographe.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: Stereoscopic viewers gave users an immersive connection to new and different places. With the invention of the cinematograph, the Lumière brothers transported viewers by projecting images of the world onto a screen in a darkened room.

start.title: The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok
start.brief_description: The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok is an American Western television series which ran for eight seasons from 1951 through 1958. The Screen Gems series began in syndication, but ran on CBS from 1955 through 1958, and, at the same time, on ABC from 1957 through 1958.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

end.title: Minecraft
end.brief_description: Minecraft is an open world game that has no specific goals for the player to accomplish, allowing players a large amount of freedom in choosing how to play the game however, there is an achievement system. The gameplay by default is first person, but players have the option to play in third person mode. The core gameplay revolves around breaking and placing blocks. The game world is essentially composed of rough 3D objects—mainly cubes—that are arranged in a fixed grid pattern and represent different materials, such as dirt, stone, various ores, water, and tree trunks. While players can move freely across the world, objects and items can only be placed at fixed locations relative to the grid. Players can gather these material blocks and place them elsewhere, thus allowing for various constructions.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: Stereoscopic viewers gave TV audiences a chance to perceive popular characters and events within a (static) 3D environment. In the VR version of Minecraft players can enter the familiar Minecraft world and see it from an entirely different perspective.

start.title: House of Wax
start.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

constellations_primary.name: Movies on wax
constellations_primary.description: Waxing lyrical about the supernatural and early 21st-century teen stars.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

end.title: How the West Was Won

video_links.name: How The West Was Won - Trailer

end.brief_description: The epic tale of the development of the American West from the 1830s through the Civil War to the end of the century, as seen through the eyes of one pioneer family.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: Along with 3D, the film industry also competed with TV by developing spectacular screening formats. Made using the three-strip Cinerama process, How the West Was Won was projected onto a huge curved screen, transporting the audience into another world.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: While the film industry was experimenting with cinematic spectacle, Tru-Vue and Viewmaster offered TV viewers a transmedia experience. Viewing cards offered 3D images of an episode relating to popular television series, such as The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok.

end.title: House of Wax
end.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

constellations_primary.name: Movies on wax
constellations_primary.description: Waxing lyrical about the supernatural and early 21st-century teen stars.

constellations_other.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_other.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

links.description: In 1934, the Lumières experimented with a 3D version of The Arrival of a Train. In the 1950s, television’s popularity encouraged filmmakers to develop the immersive possibilities of 3D. House of Wax was made in 3D colour with stereophonic sound.
